posts.post_content: A welcome addition to any Megrim centered deck. Helps with the late game problem of your opponent drawing a card and playing it before you can force a discard. Now they are stuck between possibly losing a card and 2 life or losing 5 life during their next upkeep.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
From what I've read on the community spotlight, this card is supposed to be really bad. But I disagree. This, Blightning, Nyxathid, Duress, Megrim, Hellfire Mongrel, Guul Draz Specter, Lavaclaw Reaches and some early game removal such as Smother or Bolt could make this a viable deck in the new Standard.
  
   
Are two quest counters put on it if you play one Mind rot effect?
  
   
The theory behind discard decks: If you don't have the tools to win, at least make sure that your opponent doesn't either.

posts.post_content:
Just to clarify things, when the beginning of a turn starts there are 3 steps  
  
1.Untap phase, untap all permanents unless a card's effect specifically says not to  
  
2. Upkeep phase, all card's effects affecting the beginning of the turn does so now(Ex. during your upkeep pay blah blah blah)  
  
3. Draw phase, draw a card  
  
So this card's effect happens BEFORE the card draw, so this enchantment can make it to where your opponents lose 5 life each turn
posts.html:
Just to clarify things, when the beginning of a turn starts there are 3 steps

1.Untap phase, untap all permanents unless a card's effect specifically says not to

2. Upkeep phase, all card's effects affecting the beginning of the turn does so now(Ex. during your upkeep pay blah blah blah)

3. Draw phase, draw a card

So this card's effect happens BEFORE the card draw, so this enchantment can make it to where your opponents lose 5 life each turn

posts.post_content:
To those saying this sucks because it's too hard to get your opponent's hand size down, I'd recommend you actually try playing a discard deck. Where discard decks struggle is *after* they get their opponent down to 0 cards. Since your opponent is top-decking, and most of your discard spells are sorceries, you usually can't make them discard anything, meaning you can't lock them down or get card advantage. While this card doesn't really *solve* that problem, it does make your opponent die when that happens. Which is even better.  
  
To those saying this should be an [Ascension](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ascension) and not a [Quest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quest) because you don't sacrifice it, please do your research. [Quest for Ula's Temple](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quest for Ula's Temple), [Quest for the Goblin Lord](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quest for the Goblin Lord), and [Quest for Renewal](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Quest for Renewal) all stay in play. So out of 9 Quests, 4 stay in play. Your point makes no sense whatsoever.  
  
Yes, this card has some limitations. Obviously it only goes... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:

To those saying this should be an Ascension and not a Quest because you don't sacrifice it, please do your research. Quest for Ula's Temple, Quest for the Goblin Lord, and Quest for Renewal all stay in play. So out of 9 Quests, 4 stay in play. Your point makes no sense whatsoever.

posts.post_content:
Black/blue discard mill deck... So many ways to win... So many...
  
   
Game 1: nihil stone + Horrifying revelation/inquisition + guul draz specter, then painful quandary + bloodhusk ritaulist to seal the empty hand and the win.
  
   
Game 2: Archive traps + hedron crab + tome scour + keening stone to empty the library and win just as easily. Too much fun.
  
   
I had a mix of blue/black both games but black won me the first and blue won me the second. Both in 7-8 turns.
